Description: Terracotta circular bread-stamp. A large circular bread-stamp with an applied grip (largely lost) on the centre back. It has an incuse pattern: within a bound laurel wreath is a Bacchic or dramatic mask almost to front, wearing a cap with a rolled horizontal band, ampyx, with a looped knot at each end and loops of ribbons falling on each side of the face. Locks of hair are shown below the ribbon-loops, or perhaps floral devices. Pressed over a plaster form. Micaceous red-brown Nile silt, with an overall red slip, thicker on the front than the back.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Bibliog. Walters 1903: E 50: Walters suggests that the mask represents Dionysos.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (E50)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
